christoffel.title:
Christoffel Symbols (\Gamma^{\lambda}_{\mu
u})
christoffel.definition: Christoffel symbols (of the second kind) represent the "gravitational force field" arising from the curvature of spacetime in a given coordinate system. They describe how basis vectors change from point to point and appear in the geodesic equation.
christoffel.formula:
\Gamma^{\lambda}_{\mu
u} =  rac{1}{2} g^{\lambdaho} (\partial_{\mu} g_{ho
u} + \partial_{
u} g_{ho\mu} - \partial_{ho} g_{\mu
u})

riemann.title:
Riemann Curvature Tensor (R^{ho}_{\sigma\mu
u})
riemann.definition: The Riemann tensor measures the intrinsic curvature of spacetime. It describes the tidal forces experienced by nearby objects and quantifies how vectors change when parallel-transported around a closed loop.

ricci_tensor.title:
Ricci Tensor (R_{\mu
u})
ricci_tensor.definition:
The Ricci tensor is a contraction of the Riemann tensor (R_{\mu
u} = R^{ho}_{\muho
u}). It measures how the volume of a small ball of matter changes over time due to curvature. It appears directly in the Einstein Field Equations.

ricci_scalar.title: Ricci Scalar (R)
ricci_scalar.definition:
The Ricci scalar is the trace of the Ricci tensor with respect to the inverse metric (R = g^{\mu
u} R_{\mu
u}). It represents the overall scalar curvature of spacetime at a point.

einstein_tensor.title:
Einstein Tensor (G_{\mu
u})
einstein_tensor.definition:
The Einstein tensor combines the Ricci tensor, Ricci scalar, and metric tensor. It has the crucial property of being divergence-free (
abla^{\mu} G_{\mu
u} = 0), mirroring the conservation of energy-momentum. It forms the geometric side of the Einstein Field Equations.
einstein_tensor.formula:
G_{\mu
u} = R_{\mu
u} -  rac{1}{2} g_{\mu
u} R

stress_energy_tensor.title:
Stress-Energy Tensor (T_{\mu
u})
stress_energy_tensor.definition: The stress-energy tensor describes the distribution of energy, momentum, pressure, and stress of matter and fields in spacetime. It acts as the source of gravitational fields in the Einstein Field Equations.

efe.title: Einstein Field Equations (EFE)
efe.definition:
The Einstein Field Equations relate the geometry of spacetime (represented by the Einstein tensor G_{\mu
u}) to the distribution of matter and energy (represented by the stress-energy tensor T_{\mu
u}). They form the foundation of General Relativity.
efe.formula:
G_{\mu
u} =  rac{8\pi G}{c^4} T_{\mu
u} \quad 	ext{(or } G_{\mu
u} = \kappa T_{\mu
u} 	ext{ in chosen units)}

geodesic_equation.title: Geodesic Equation
geodesic_equation.definition: The geodesic equation describes the path of freely falling particles (timelike geodesics) or light rays (null geodesics) through curved spacetime. It involves the Christoffel symbols.

flamms_paraboloid.title: Flamm's Paraboloid
flamms_paraboloid.definition: Flamm's paraboloid is an embedding diagram that visualizes the spatial curvature of the equatorial plane (t=const, 	heta=\pi/2) of the Schwarzschild metric. It embeds the 2D curved surface into flat 3D Euclidean space.
flamms_paraboloid.formula: ds^2 =  rac{dr^2}{1 - 2M/r} + r^2 d\phi^2 \implies z(r) = \int \sqrt{ rac{2M/r}{1-2M/r}} dr = \sqrt{8M(r-2M)}
